_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary for Bayer CropScience (BCS)

This March 2010 risk management plan (RMP) has been updated as a result of plans to operate a currently idled process that will use a regulated substance (phosphorus trichloride). All sections of the RMP have been updated.

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Bayer CropScience is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility.  We regularly assess the risks associated with the use of chemicals in our manufacturing processes using tools such as Hazard and Operability studies, and we seek out ways in which to reduce those risks.  It is our policy to proactively implement appropriate measures to prevent possible releases. If such a release does occur, our highly-trained on-site emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  BCS has maintained a long-standing working relationship with the Kansas City, Missouri emergency response community including HAZMAT 71 that ensures their support in the event of an unexpected release.

2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

The primary activities at our facility are the formulation and manufacture of crop protection chemicals.  There are nine regulated chemicals present at our facility. These chemicals are essential raw materials for the production of crop protection products, and are: 1) carbon disulfide, 2) chlorine, 3) ethyl mercaptan, 4) formaldehyde (solution), 5) hydrazine, 6) methyl butene, 7) vinyl chloride, 8) anhydrous hydrogen chloride, and 9) phosphorus trichloride.  

3. Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

BCS has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental r

elease prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68.  This manufacturing facility was designed and constructed generally in accordance with NFPA-58, which was in effect at the time of construction.  A number of processes at our facility are subject to the OSHA PSM standard under 29 CFR 1910.119.  The facility is also subject to the Spill Prevention, Control, and Countermeasure Plan (SPCC) under 40 CFR 112, the RCRA Preparedness and Prevention regulations and Contingency Plan and Emergency Procedures under Subpart C and D of 40 CFR 264, and EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements. In addition, the facility is also subject to the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard (CFATS) under 6 CFR 27.  

4. Five-year Accident History

BCS has an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last five years.  There has been only one RMP reportable accidental release during this period. No one was injured as a result of the incident; there was only on-site property damage.

5. Emergency Response Program

BCS maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.

BCS has an on-site emergency brigade comprised of approximately 60 employees providing coverage 24 hours per day and 365 days per year.  The brigade is trained to mitigate fire, medical, hazardous material, and rescue emergencies.  BCS also has a trained Technician and Incident Command level HAZMAT team with approximately 15 employees available for emergencies when necessary.  The HAZMAT team and emergency brigade provide initial response for any emergencies that may occur.

To ensure proper functioning, emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is reviewed annu

ally and updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response strategy.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Kansas City site is regulated under CFATS and is in full compliance with security plan submittal requirements. Security upgrades are in progress that will greatly reduce the possibility of an act of aggression leading to a release of an RMP regulated chemical. Security upgrades will be made within the timeframe agreed upon with the Department of Homeland Security.

Additionally, the facility has computer based process control system upgrades in progress on processes using six of the nine RMP regulated chemicals. The facility has also been working with the supplier of one of its RMP regulated chemicals to improve the safety and reliability of the delivery trailers and of the unloading operation.
